'''The Pirate Bay''' (commonly abbreviated '''TPB''') is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] website which hosts [[Magnet URI scheme|magnet links]] and [[BitTorrent (protocol)|.torrent]] files, which allow users to share electronic files, including multimedia, computer games and software via [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]]. The Pirate Bay bills itself as "The world's most resilient BitTorrent site"<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=1 October 2008|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/01/technology/01pirate.html?_r=1&scp=3&sq=Swedes%20charge%204%20in%20case%20involving%20copyright%20infringement%20of%20music%20and%20films|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080203103037/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/01/31/business/pirate.php|archivedate=3 February 2008|title=Swedes charge 4 in case involving copyright infringement of music and films |work=International Herald Tribune|date=31 January 2008|author=Pfanner, Eric }}</ref> and is currently ranked as the 77th most visited website in the world and 14th in Sweden by [[Alexa Internet]]<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/thepiratebay.org |title= Thepiratebay.org Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2011-10-02 }}</ref>, has over 5 million registered users and, as of 2011, hosts more than 3.5 million torrent files.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freakbits.com/the-pirate-bay-welcomes-its-4-millionth-user-1209 |title=The Pirate Bay Welcomes Its 4 Millionth User|publisher=FreakBits |date=9 December 2009 |accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', The Pirate Bay is "one of the world's largest facilitators of illegal downloading" and "the most visible member of a burgeoning international [[anti-copyright]] or pro-piracy movement".<ref name="latimes1">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-ca-webscout29apr29,0,1261622.story?coll=la-home-entertainment |title=The Internet sure loves its outlaws â Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimes.com |date= 29 April 2007|accessdate=28 September 2008 | first=David | last=Sarno}}</ref>
Initially established in November 2003 by the Swedish [[anti-copyright]] organization [[PiratbyrÃ¥n]] (The Piracy Bureau), The Pirate Bay has been run as a separate organization since October 2004. The Pirate Bay was first run by [[Gottfrid Svartholm]] and [[Fredrik Neij]], who are known by their nicknames "anakata" and "TiAMO", respectively. They have both been accused by the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] with "assisting in making copyrighted content available". On 31 May 2006, the website's servers in [[Stockholm]] were raided and taken away by Swedish police, leading to three days of [[downtime]].<ref name=still /> The Pirate Bay has been involved in a number of lawsuits, both as plaintiff and as defendant. On 17 April 2009, [[Peter Sunde]], [[Fredrik Neij]], [[Gottfrid Svartholm]] and [[Carl LundstrÃ¶m]] were found guilty of [[Accessory (legal term)|assistance]] to [[copyright infringement]] and sentenced to one year in prison and payment of a fine of 30 million [[Swedish krona|SEK]] (app. 4,200,000 [[United States dollar|USD]]; 2,800,000 [[Pound sterling|GBP]]; or 3,100,000 [[Euro|EUR]]), after a [[The Pirate Bay trial|trial]] of nine days. The defendants have appealed against the verdict and the judge was accused of bias.<ref>[http://torrentfreak.com/the-pirate-bay-trial-the-verdict-090417/ The Pirate Bay Trial: The Official Verdict â Guilty]. [[Torrentfreak.com|Torrent Freak]]. Retrieved 17 April 2009.</ref> On 26 November 2010, a Swedish appeals court returned the verdict, decreasing the original prison terms but increasing the fine to 46 million SEK.<ref name="AppealVerdict">{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hgV9yJkx_IcxxnMJEAZQkoA4ESwg?docId=CNG.221f09c221a1979e755e0b0622ce97cd.c01|title=Prison terms of Pirate Bay executives' shortened|publisher=AFP|date=26 November 2010|accessdate=26 November 2010}}</ref> On 17 May 2010, due to an injunction against their bandwidth provider, the site was taken offline.<ref name="Injunction">{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/196501/german_injunction_knocks_the_pirate_bay_offline_temporarily.html|title=German Injunction Knocks The Pirate Bay Offline Temporarily â PCWorld|work=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|accessdate=18 May 2010}}</ref> Access to the website was later restored with a message making fun of the injunction on their front page. On 23 June 2010 the group PiratbyrÃ¥n disbanded due to the death of Ibi [[Kopimi]] Botani, a prominent member and co-founder of the group.<ref name="GoneForGood">{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/pirate-bays-founding-group-piratbyran-disbands-100623/|title=The Pirate Bay â Disbands|publisher=[[TorrentFreak.com|Torrent Freak]]|date=23 June 2010|accessdate=24 June 2010}}</ref>

The Pirate Bay is hosted by [[PRQ]], a Sweden-based company, owned by creators of TPB Gottfrid Svartholm and Fredrik Neij.<ref>HÃ¤yhtiÃ¶, Tapio. ''Net working/Networking'', Tampere University Press, p. 344, 2008.</ref> PRQ is said to provide "highly secure, no-questions-asked hosting services to its customers."<ref>Goodin, Dan. [[Serious Tubes Networks]] is currently providing network connectivity to The Pirate Bay.<ref name=torrentfreak-comcast>{{cite news |date=12 May 2011 |author=Ernesto Van Der Sar |title=Comcast Offers Help to The Pirate Bay, Problems Fixed |publisher=[[TorrentFreak]] |url=http://torrentfreak.com/comcast-offers-help-to-the-pirate-bay-110512/ }}</ref>
===Website setup=== The Pirate Bay allows users to search for and download [[torrent file|BitTorrent files (torrents)]], small files that contain [[metadata]] necessary to download the data files from other users. The torrents are organized into categories: "music", "Video" (including a 3D section), "Applications", "Games", "Other" and "Porn".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepiratebay.org/browse|title=Browse torrents|publisher=thepiratebay.org|accessdate=1 February 2009}}</ref> Normally the "Porn" category is only visible for registered and logged-in users who select the "show pornographic torrents" option in their settings page. However it is currently not necessary with a workaround, allowing unregistered users to search for the content, but not browse through it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepiratebay.org/browse|title=Browse torrents|publisher=thepiratebay.org|accessdate=1 August 2010}}</ref> Registration requires an email address and is free; registered users may upload their own torrents and comment on torrents.
The website features a browse function that enables users to see what is available in broad categories like Audio, Video, and Games, as well as sub-categories like Audio books, High-res Movies, and Comics. The contents of a category can be sorted by file name, the number of seeds or leechers, the date posted, etc.
According to [[PiratbyrÃ¥n]], The Pirate Bay is a long-running project of [[performance art]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog/101 |title=All your bus are belong to us!|author=<nowiki>#</nowiki>kopiermich|work=[http://thepiratebay.org/blog Blog]|publisher=thepiratebay.org |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref> Normally the front page of The Pirate Bay features a drawing of a [[pirate]] ship with the logo of the 1980s anti-copyright infringement campaign, ''[[Home Taping Is Killing Music]]'', on its sails.<ref>{{cite news |first=Marie |last=Lechner |date=7 December 2007 |title=La K7 bande encore |url=http://www.liberation.fr/culture/0101117124-la-k7-bande-encore |work=[[LibÃ©ration]] |language=French }}</ref>
===Technical details=== Initially, The Pirate Bay's four [[Linux]] [[Server (computing)|servers]] ran a custom [[web server]] called Hypercube. An old version is open source.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/3903397/hypercube_tracker_by_anakata |title=hypercube tracker by anakata |author=[http://thepiratebay.org/user/JooiZe/ JooiZe]|date=21 November 2007|work=Browse Torrents |publisher=thepiratebay.org}}</ref><!-- torrent still live--><ref>{{cite web|author=| url=http://junki.es/hypercube-dist.tar.bz2 |title=Hypercube-dist.tar.bz2 |format=BZ2 archive| date=15 November 2008 |publisher=Junki.es |accessdate=12 July 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> On 1 June 2005, The Pirate Bay updated its website in an effort to reduce [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidth]] usage, which was reported to be at 2 [[HTTP]] requests per [[millisecond]] on each of the four [[web server]]s,<ref name=stay>{{cite news|url=http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/03/70358|title=The Pirate Bay: Here to Stay?|date=13 March 2006 |first=Ann |last=Harrison |publisher=''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''|accessdate=21 June 2008}}</ref> as well as to create a more user friendly interface for the [[front-end]] of the website. The website now runs [[Lighttpd]] and [[PHP]] on its dynamic front ends, [[MySQL]] at the database back end, [[Sphinx (search engine)|Sphinx]] on the two search systems, [[memcached]] for caching SQL queries and PHP-sessions, and [[Varnish cache|Varnish]] in front of Lighttpd for caching static content. {{As of|September 2008}}, The Pirate Bay consisted of 31 dedicated servers including nine dynamic web fronts, a database, two search engines, and eight BitTorrent trackers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://static.thepiratebay.org/ |title=Technical specifications |publisher=The Pirate Bay |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref>
On 7 December 2007, The Pirate Bay finished the move from Hypercube to [[Opentracker]] as its BitTorrent tracking software, also enabling the use of the [[User Datagram Protocol|UDP]] tracker protocol for which Hypercube lacked support.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=29 September 2008|url=http://torrentfreak.com/the-pirate-bay-switches-to-opentracker-071208/|title=The Pirate Bay Now Running on Opentracker |publisher=[[Torrentfreak.com|Torrent Freak]]|date=8 December 2007|author="Ernesto" }}</ref> This allowed UDP [[multicast]] to be used to synchronize the multiple servers with each other much faster than before.<ref>Roettgers, Janko (15 July 2009) [http://www.salon.com/technology/the_gigaom_network/online_video/2009/07/14/post_pirate_bay_a_federated_tracker_network_emerges/index.html "Post-Pirate Bay, a Federated Tracker Network Emerges"], [[Salon.com]]</ref> Opentracker is free software.<ref>[http://erdgeist.org/arts/software/opentracker/ "opentracker â An open and free bittorrent tracker"]. License: [[Beerware]]. [http://opentracker.blog.h3q.com/2009/01/01/beerware-dreams/ "Beerware dreams"], [http://torrentfreak.com/pirate-party-fulfills-opentrackers-beerware-license-081231/ "Pirate Party fulfills Opentracker's Beerware license".]</ref>
In June 2008, The Pirate Bay announced that their servers would support [[Secure Sockets Layer|SSL]] encryption (accessible via https://thepiratebay.org)<!-- make explicit, once.--> in response to Sweden's new wiretapping law.<ref name="SlyckSSL">{{cite web|url=http://www.slyck.com/story1691_SSL_Encrpytion_Coming_to_The_Pirate_Bay|title=SSL Encryption Coming to The Pirate Bay|last=Mennecke|first=Thomas|date=22 June 2008|publisher=[[Slyck News]]|accessdate=10 August 2008}}</ref><ref name="GuarSSL">Schofield, Jack (23 June 2008). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/blog/2008/jun/23/thepiratebaywillusesslto "The Pirate Bay will use SSL to fight the law"]. [[The Guardian]]. Retrieved 13 July 2010.</ref>
On 19 January 2009, The Pirate Bay launched [[IPv6]] support for their tracker system, using an IPv6-only version of [[Opentracker]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog/146|title=IPv6 support|author=bkp|work=Blog|publisher=The Pirate Bay|date=19 January 2009|accessdate=12 July 2010}}</ref>
On 17 November 2009, The Pirate Bay shut off its tracker service permanently, stating that centralized trackers are no longer needed since [[distributed hash table]]s (DHT), [[peer exchange]] (PEX), and [[Magnet URI scheme|magnet links]] allow peers to find each other and content in a decentralized way.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slyck.com/story1880_The_Pirate_Bay_Trackers_Go_Offline_Forever| title=The Pirate Bay Trackers Go Offline Forever| date=17 November 2009| author=Mennecke, Thomas |publisher=[[Slyck.com]] |accessdate=15 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.se/23310/20091117/ |title=Scrapping tracker may negate Pirate Bay fines |author=Landes, David |publisher=[[The Local]] |work=thelocal.se |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=15 July 2010}}</ref>
==Funding== Petter Nilsson, a candidate on the Swedish political reality show ''Toppkandidaterna'' (''The Top Candidates''), donated 35,000 [[Swedish Krona|SEK]] (US$4,925.83) to The Pirate Bay, which they used to buy new servers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog/25 |title=The First State Financed Tracker |author="tbz"|work=[http://thepiratebay.org/blog Blog]|publisher=thepiratebay.org |date=5 May 2006 |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref> {{as of|2006|6}}, the website is financed through advertisements on their result pages. According to speculations by ''Svenska Dagbladet'', the advertisements generate about 600,000 SEK (US$84,442.80) per month.<ref>{{cite web |first=Staffan |last=Olsson |date=8 July 2006 |url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/pirate-bay-drar-in-miljonbelopp_334410.svd |title=Pirate Bay drar in miljonbelopp |language=Swedish |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |accessdate=28 September 2008}} ([http://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A//www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/pirate-bay-drar-in-miljonbelopp_334410.svd&hl=en&langpair=auto|en&tbb=1&ie=UTF-8 English tr.])</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=8 July 2006 |url=http://rixstep.com/1/20060708,00.shtml |title=TPB Raking in Millions |publisher=[[Rixstep]] |accessdate=25 April 2009}}</ref> In an investigation in 2006, the police concluded that The Pirate Bay brings in 1.2 million SEK (US$168,885.60) per year from advertisements.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ivar |last=Andersen |title=RÃ¤ttegÃ¥ngen mot The pirate bay: Ã klagaren yrkar pÃ¥ fÃ¤ngelse |work=[[Fria Tidningen]] |language=Swedish |date=2 March 2009 |url=http://www.fria.nu/artikel/78204 }}([http://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A//www.fria.nu/artikel/78204&hl=en&langpair=auto|en&tbb=1&ie=UTF-8 English tr.])</ref> The prosecution estimated in the 2009 trial from emails and screenshots that the advertisements pay over 10 million SEK (US$1.40738M) a year,<ref>{{cite web |date=2 March 2009 |first=Sam |last=Sundberg |title=TPB har tjÃ¤nat tio miljoner om Ã¥ret |url=http://blogg.svd.se/thepiratebay?ID=12244 |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |format=blog| accessdate=20 April 2009 }}([http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fblogg.svd.se%2Fthepiratebay%3FID%3D12244 English tr.])</ref> but in the indictment used the estimate from the police investigation.<ref>{{cite web |first=Oscar |last=Swartz |date=2 March 2009 |title=Var Ã¤r mina tio miljoner? |url=http://nyheter24.se/nyheter/blogg/oscar-swartz/146685-swartz-var-ar-mina-tio-miljoner |format=blog |publisher=Nyheter24 |language=Swedish |accessdate=20 April 2009 }}([http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fnyheter24.se%2Fnyheter%2Fblogg%2Foscar-swartz%2F146685-swartz-var-ar-mina-tio-miljoner English tr.])</ref> The lawyers of the site's administrators counted the 2006 revenue closer to 725,000 SEK (US$102,035.05).<ref name=kuprijanko>{{cite news |first=Alexander |last=Kuprijanko |title=FÃ¶rsvaret: verksamheten Ã¤r laglig |publisher=[[Sydsvenskan]] |language=Swedish |date=3 March 2009 |url=http://sydsvenskan.se/sverige/article417153/Forsvaret-verksamheten-ar-laglig.html }} ([http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fsydsvenskan.se%2Fsverige%2Farticle417153%2FForsvaret-verksamheten-ar-laglig.html English tr.])</ref> The verdict of the trial however quoted the estimate from the preliminary investigation.<ref>[http://www.sr.se/Diverse/AppData/Isidor/files/83/6277.pdf Dom 17 April 2009 i mÃ¥l nr B 13301-06](PDF). Stockholms tingsrÃ¤tt. {{sv icon}}</ref>
In April 2007, a rumor was confirmed on the Swedish talk show ''Bert'' that The Pirate Bay had received financial support from right-wing entrepreneur [[Carl LundstrÃ¶m]]. This caused some furor since LundstrÃ¶m, an heir to the [[WasabrÃ¶d]] fortune, is known for financing several far-right political parties and movements like [[Sverigedemokraterna]] and [[Bevara Sverige Svenskt]] (''Keep Sweden Swedish''). During the talk show, [[PiratbyrÃ¥n]] spokesman Tobias Andersson acknowledged that "without LundstrÃ¶m's support, Pirate Bay would not have been able to start" and claimed that most of the money went towards acquiring servers and bandwidth.<ref name="Regrightwing">{{cite web|accessdate=28 September 2008|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/05/07/pirate_bay_accepted_right_wing_money/|title=The Pirate Bay admits links with right-wing benefactor |publisher=The Register|date=7 May 2007|author=Jibbenga, Jan }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Konrad |last=Lischka |date=4 May 2007 |url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/web/0,1518,480972,00.html |title=Piratenseite im Zwielicht: Rechtspopulist finanziert Internet-TauschbÃ¶rse |publisher=[[Der Spiegel]] |language=German |accessdate=28 September 2008}} ([http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.spiegel.de%2Fnetzwelt%2Fweb%2F0%2C1518%2C480972%2C00.html English tr.])</ref>
The [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] (IFPI) claims that the website is extremely profitable, and that The Pirate Bay is more engaged in making profit than supporting people's rights.<ref name=arsfabricated>{{cite news |date=1 February 2008 |first=Ryan |last=Paul|accessdate=29 September 2008|url=http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2008/02/pirate-bay-big-revenue-claims-fabricated-by-prosecutors.ars|title=Pirate Bay: big revenue claims fabricated by prosecutors |publisher=Ars Technica }}</ref> The website has insisted that these allegations are not true, stating, "It's not free to operate a Web Site on this scale," and, "If we were making lots of money I, [[Svartholm]], wouldn't be working late at the office tonight, I'd be sitting on a beach somewhere, working on my tan."<ref>{{cite web|author=Daly, Steven|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/ontheweb/features/2007/03/piratebay200703?currentPage=4 |title=Pirates of the Multiplex|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|month= March | year= 2007|accessdate=14 February 2007}}</ref> In response to claims of annual revenue exceeding US$3 million made by the IFPI, the site's spokesman Peter Sunde argues that the website's high bandwidth, power, and hardware costs eliminate the potential for profit. The Pirate Bay, he says, may ultimately be operating at a loss.<ref name=arsfabricated /> In the 2009 trial, the defense estimated the site's yearly expenses to be 800,000 SEK (US$112,590.40).<ref name=kuprijanko /> It is possible to make donations to the Pirate Bay and the site also ran a fund intended to buy [[Principality of Sealand|Sealand]], a platform with debated [[Micronation|micro-nation]] status.
==Incidents== ===Raid=== {{Main|The Pirate Bay raid}}
On 31 May 2006, a raid against The Pirate Bay and people involved with the website took place as ordered by judge Tomas NorstrÃ¶m, later the presiding judge of the 2009 trial, prompted by allegations of copyright violations. Police officers shut down the website and confiscated its servers, as well as all other servers hosted by The Pirate Bay's [[Internet service provider]], [[PRQ]]. The company is owned by two operators of The Pirate Bay. Three people â [[Gottfrid Svartholm]], Mikael Viborg, and [[Fredrik Neij]] â were held by the police for questioning, but were released later that evening.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=1 October 2008|url=http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/08/71543?currentPage=all|title=Secrets of The Pirate Bay |work=Wired|date=16 August 2006|author=Norton, Quinn }}</ref> All servers in the room were seized, including those running the website of [[PiratbyrÃ¥n]], an independent organization fighting for file sharing rights, as well as servers unrelated to The Pirate Bay or other file sharing activities, including a Russian opposition news agency. Equipment such as hardware routers, switches, blank CDs, and fax machines were also seized.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=1 June 2006|date=1 June 2006|url=http://thepiratebay.org/|title= Homepage|publisher=thepiratebay.org|quote=The police officers were allowed access to the racks where the Pirate Bay servers and other servers are hosted. All servers in the racks were clearly marked as to which sites run on each. The police took down all servers in the racks, including the non-commercial site PiratbyrÃ¥n}}</ref>
The [[Motion Picture Association of America]] (MPAA) wrote in a press release: "Since filing a criminal complaint in Sweden in November 2004, the film industry has worked vigorously with Swedish and U.S. government officials in Sweden to shut this illegal website down." MPAA CEO [[Dan Glickman]] also stated, "Intellectual property theft is a problem for film industries all over the world and we are glad that the local government in Sweden has helped stop The Pirate Bay from continuing to enable rampant copyright theft on the Internet." The MPAA press release set forth its justification for the raid and claimed that there were three arrests; however, the individuals were not actually arrested, only held for questioning. The release also reprinted John G. Malcolm's allegation that The Pirate Bay was making money from the distribution of copyrighted material, a criticism denied by the Pirate Bay.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Swedish authorities sink Pirate Bay|url=http://www.mpaa.org/press_releases/2006_05_31.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=[[Motion Picture Association of America]]|date=31 May 2006| archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ludmVPre |archivedate=10 December 2009| accessdate=27 September 2008}}</ref>
After the raid, The Pirate Bay displayed a message that confirmed that the Swedish police had executed search warrants for breach of copyright law or assisting such a breach. The closure message initially caused some confusion because on 1 April 2005, [[April Fool's Day]], The Pirate Bay had posted a similar message as a [[prank]], stating that they were unavailable due to a raid by the Swedish Anti-Piracy Bureau and [[IFPI]]. PiratbyrÃ¥n set up a temporary news [[blog]] to inform the public about the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://piratbyran.blogspot.com/ |title=PiratbyrÃ¥n â temporÃ¤r nyhetsfÃ¶rmedling |publisher=Piratbyran.blogspot.com |date= 1 May 2006 |accessdate=28 September 2008 |language=Swedish}} ([http://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A//piratbyran.blogspot.com/2006_05_01_archive.html&hl=en&langpair=auto|en&tbb=1&ie=UTF-8 English tr.])</ref> On 2 June 2006, The Pirate Bay was available once again, with their logo depicting a pirate ship firing cannon balls at the [[Hollywood sign]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/tech/piratebay.html|title=The Pirate Bay |publisher=CBC|date=9 June 2006|author=Bowman, John |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref>
[[Image:Fredrik Neij - 2006-06-03 (Jon Ã slund).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Fredrik Neij]] (alias TiAMO) speaking at [[Mynttorget]] in [[Stockholm]] during the 3 June 2006 pro-piracy protest]]
The Pirate Bay has servers in both Belgium and Russia which may be used in the future in case of another raid.<ref name="RegResurfaces">{{cite web|accessdate=1 October 2008|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/06/05/pirate_bay_reemerges/|title=Pirate Bay resurfaces,while protesters walk the street |work=The Register|date=5 June 2006|author=Libbenga, Jan }}</ref> According to The Pirate Bay, in the two years following the raid, it grew from one million to 2.7 million registered users and from 2.5 million to 12 million peers.<ref name=still>{{cite web|accessdate=29 September 2008|url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog/111|title=Two years and still going |author="''In memory of tracker-data''"|work=[http://thepiratebay.org/blog Blog]|publisher=thepiratebay.org|date=31 May 2008}}</ref> The Pirate Bay now claims more than twenty-five million active users.<ref name="latimes1"/>
Sweden's largest technology museum, the [[Swedish National Museum of Science and Technology]], acquired one of the confiscated servers in 2009 and placed it in an exhibit for having great symbolic value as a "big problem or a big opportunity".<ref>[http://www.tekniskamuseet.se/1/259.html The Pirate Bays server pÃ¥ Tekniska museet] (in Swedish). The [[Peer-to-peer|P2P]] news [[blog]], [[Torrentfreak.com|Torrent Freak]], reported on 12 October 2007 that the Internet domain ifpi.com, which previously belonged to the [[IFPI|International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]], an anti-piracy organisation, had been acquired by The Pirate Bay. ===Autopsy photos=== In September 2008, the Swedish media reported that the public preliminary investigation protocols concerning a child murder case known as the [[Christine SchÃ¼rrer|Arboga case]] had been made available through a torrent on The Pirate Bay. ===Legal issues=== {{See also|The Pirate Bay trial}} In September 2007, a large number of internal emails were leaked from anti-piracy company [[MediaDefender]] by an anonymous hacker. Some of the leaked emails discussed hiring [[hacker (computer security)|hackers]] to perform [[Denial-of-service attack|DDOS attacks]] on The Pirate Bay's servers and trackers.<ref name=bbchistory>{{cite news |first=Flora |last=Graham |title=How The Pirate Bay sailed into infamy |date=16 February 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7893223.stm |publisher=BBC News }}</ref> In response to the leak, The Pirate Bay filed charges in Sweden against MediaDefender clients [[Twentieth Century Fox]] Sweden AB, [[EMI]] Sweden AB, [[Universal Music Group]] Sweden AB, [[Universal Pictures]] Nordic AB, [[Paramount Home Entertainment]] (Sweden) AB, [[Atari]] Nordic AB, [[Activision]] Nordic, [[Ubisoft]] Sweden AB, [[Sony BMG Music Entertainment]] (Sweden) AB, and [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment]] Nordic AB,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/ekonomi/pirate-bay-till-attack-mot-skiv-och-filmbranschen-1.591571 |title=Pirate Bay till attack mot skiv- och filmbranschen |publisher=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |first=Mia |last=HallerÃ¶d |coauthors=Wiklander, Daniel |language=Swedish |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref> but the charges were not pursued.<ref name=bbchistory /> MediaDefender's stocks fell sharply after this incident, and several media companies withdrew from the service after the company announced the leak had caused $825,000 in losses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/mediadefender-stock-plunges-due-to-leaked-emails-071222/ |title=MediaDefender Stock Plunges Due to Leaked Emails |publisher=[[Torrentfreak.com|Torrent Freak]] |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref> Later, The Pirate Bay co-founder [[Peter Sunde]] accused police investigator Jim Keyzer of a conflict of interest when he declined to investigate MediaDefender. ===Service issues=== In May 2007, The Pirate Bay was attacked by a group of [[Hacker (computer security)|hackers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog/68 |title=User data stolen but not unsecured |author=bkp|work=[http://thepiratebay.org/blog Blog]|publisher=thepiratebay.org |date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref> They copied the user database, which included over 1.5 million users. The Pirate Bay reassured its users that the data was of no value and that passwords and e-mails were [[encrypted]] and [[Hash function|hashed]]. Some blogs stated that a group known as the AUH (Arga Unga Hackare, Swedish for "Angry Young Hackers") were suspected of executing the attack, however the AUH stated on the ''Computer Sweden'' newspaper that they were not involved and would take revenge on those responsible for the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://powerofthought.wordpress.com/2007/05/11/the-pirate-bay-infiltrated/ |title=The Pirate Bay Infiltrated " Power of Thought |publisher=Powerofthought.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://computersweden.idg.se/2.2683/1.107659/ |title="AUH inte bakom hacket" â Computer Sweden |publisher=International Data Group |date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref>
On 27 April 2009 the website of The Pirate Bay had [[Fiber-optic communication|fiber]] [[IPv4]] connectivity issues. There was widespread speculation this was a forced outage from the Swedish antipiracy group, accelerated somewhat by TPB adding contact details for the Swedish antipiracy group's lawyers to its [[RIPE NCC|RIPE]] database record.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thepiratebay.org/blog/152 |title=Fiber problems |quote=The site and tracker were down during most of the night and morning due to a broken fiber connection|date=27 April 2009|author= TiAMO|publisher=The Pirate Bay|accessdate=26 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/pirate-bay-ips-assigned-to-prosecution-lawyers-090426/|title=Pirate Bay IP Addresses Assigned to Prosecution Lawyers|publisher=[[Torrentfreak.com|Torrent Freak]]|date=26 April 2009|accessdate=26 April 2009}}</ref> The site and its forums were still available via [[IPv6]] at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://suprbay.org/showthread.php?t=32588&page=46 |title=The Pirate Bay â fiber cut|publisher=suprbay.org |date= |accessdate=27 April 2009}}{{dead link|date=December 2010}}</ref>
On 24 August 2009 one of The Pirate Bay's upstream providers was ordered to discontinue service for the website by a Swedish court in response to a [[civil action]] brought by several entertainment companies including [[Disney]], [[Universal Studios Home Entertainment|Universal]], [[Time Warner]], [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia]], [[Sony]], [[NBC]], and [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]]. According to the Pirate Bay blog, this caused a [[downtime]] of 3 hours,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://thepiratebay.org/blog/171|title=Wireless TPB|author=the spirit of TPB|work=[http://thepiratebay.org/blog Blog]|publisher=thepiratebay.org|date=24 August 2009| accessdate=25 August 2009}}</ref> however some users were unable to access the site immediately following the relocation due to unrelated technical difficulties. The site was fully operational again for everyone within 24 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2009/08/25/pirate-bay-shut-down.html |title=Pirate Bay lives on through drama |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=25 August 2009 |accessdate=25 August 2009 }}</ref>
On 6 October 2009, one of the IP transit providers to The Pirate Bay blocked all Pirate Bay traffic causing an outage for most users around the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-10367767-93.html |title=Hollywood hunts The Pirate Bay; site down again |author=Greg Sandoval |date=5 October 2009 |publisher=CBS Interactive Inc |work=CNET News}}</ref> On 6 October 2009, the site was back online at an IP address at [[CyberBunker]], located in the Netherlands.<ref name=TFbunker>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/the-pirate-bay-relocates-to-a-nuclear-bunker-091006/ |title=The Pirate Bay Relocates to a Nuclear Bunker |publisher=[[Torrentfreak.com|Torrent Freak]] |date=6 October 2009 |accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> It is not known whether The Pirate Bay is actually located at CyberBunker or whether they are using the CyberBunker service that routes Cyberbunker IP addresses to any datacenter around the world. These routes are not visible from the outside world.

===Facebook=== After The Pirate Bay introduced a feature in March 2009 to easily share links to torrents on the popular [[social networking]] site [[Facebook]], [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] found in May that Facebook had started blocking the links. ===Belgium=== A court has overturned a 2010 ruling which said that blocking The Pirate Bay at the ISP level was âdisproportionateâ. The [[Antwerp]] Court of Appeal sided with the Belgian Anti-Piracy Federation in their quest to force two ISPs to block subscriber access to TPB. Belgacom and Telenet must implement a DNS blockade of the site within 14 days or face fines.<ref name=BelgianCourtRuling>{{cite web|url=http://nurpa.be/files/20111004_BAF-Belgacom-Telenet-DNS-blocking.pdf|title=Antwerp Appeals Court Ruling: BAF vs Belgacom and Telenet - DNS Blocking (in Dutch, citing the original ruling it overturns)|publisher=nurpa.be}}</ref>
After the founders of The Pirate Bay lost their 2009 trial, the Belgian Anti-Piracy Foundation (BAF) began pushing two ISPs â Belgacom and Telenet â to block subscriber access to the famous torrent site.<ref name=BelgianCourtRuling/>
After year-long negotiations between the trio broke down, legal action was the inevitable outcome and in July 2010 their first battle came to a conclusion.<ref name=BelgianCourtRuling/>
The Antwerp Commercial Court decided that neither [[ISP]] would have to block TPB and went on to describe the notion of wholesale site blocking as âdisproportionateâ.<ref name=BelgianCourtRuling/>
The ISPs said it wasnât their position to decide which sites can and can not be accessed by their users. BAF accused them of providing a safe-haven to The Pirate Bay and filed an appeal. The Antwerp Court of Appeal overruled the decision of the Commercial Court and has ordered [[Belgacom]] and [[Telenet]] to initiate DNS blockades of 11 domains connected to The Pirate Bay within 14 days or face fines.<ref name=BelgianCourtRuling/>
A Pirate Bay spokesperson told that this measure will only have the opposite effect, as there are many ways to circumvent it. âThis will just give us more traffic, as always. Thanks for the free advertising.â<ref>{{cite web|url=http://activepolitic.com:82/News/2011-10-04a/Belgian_ISPs_Ordered_To_Block_The_Pirate_Bay.html|title=Belgian ISPs Ordered To Block The Pirate Bay|publisher=activepolitic.com}}</ref>
The court order has a limitative list of domain names to block, which all include 'www.'. The equivalent URLs without 'www.' are also blocked by ISPs who want to comply with the "spirit of the law" even though the court order doesn't specify that. <ref name=BelgianCourtRuling/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://yro.slashdot.org/story/11/10/08/2327227/belgian-court-order-may-be-too-specific-to-actually-block-pirate-bay-domain|title=Belgian Court Order May Be Too Specific To Actually Block Pirate Bay Domain|publisher=slashdot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://activepolitic.com:82/News/2011-10-08/Belgium_May_Not_be_Blocking_The_Pirate_Bay.html|title=Belgium May Not be Blocking The Pirate Bay|publisher=activepolitic.com}}</ref>
NURPA, a nonprofit Belgian advocacy group which promotes and protects digital rights, freedom of expression, privacy and civil liberties, condemn the decision: âThe decision of the Antwerp Court of Appeal in the case against Belgacom BAF / Telenet sets a dangerous precedent for blocking of content by Internet service providers in Belgium. It is incompatible with the doctrine of proportionality advocated by the European Court of Human Rights,â says Loconte.<ref name=NurpaReaction>{{cite web|url=http://nurpa.be/actualites/2011/10/BAF-belgacom-telenet-blocage-dns|title=BAF contre Telenet / Belgacom, les opÃ©rateurs devront bloquer The Pirate Bay (in french)|publisher=nurpa.be}}</ref>
By imposing a site-wide blockade, Loconte says the Court of Appeal has disproportionately censored all content indexed by the site, including legitimately available material.<ref name=NurpaReaction/>
On Oct 5th, The Pirate Bay registered the domain name depiraatbaai.be, allowing Belgian users to access the site again, even without using alternative dns providers, proving the limits of the court ruling already described by the defendants in their arguments to the court.<ref>dns.be search for depiraatbaai.be</ref>

==Trial== {{Main|The Pirate Bay trial}} The Pirate Bay trial was a joint [[criminal law|criminal]] and [[civil law (legal system)|civil]] prosecution in Sweden of four individuals charged for promoting the [[copyright infringement]] of others with The Pirate Bay site.<ref name=kravets>{{cite web |first=David |last=Kravets |url=http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2008/01/pirate-bay-futu.html |title=Pirate Bay Future Uncertain After Operators Busted |work=Threat Level |publisher=[[Wired News]] Blogs |date=31 January 2008 |accessdate=28 September 2008}}</ref><ref name=larsson>{{cite web |first=Linus |last=Larsson |url=http://www.idg.se/2.1085/1.143146 |title=Charges filed against the Pirate Bay four|work=[[Computer Sweden]]|date=31 January 2008|accessdate=1 February 2008}}</ref> The criminal charges were supported by a consortium of [[intellectual rights]] holders led by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry [[IFPI]], who filed individual civil compensation claims against the owners of The Pirate Bay.<ref name=TIME>{{cite news |first=Michael A. |last=Lindenberger |date=20 February 2009 |title=Internet Pirates Face Walking the Plank in Sweden |url=http://www.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1880981,00.html |work=[[TIME]] }}</ref>
Swedish [[prosecutor]]s filed charges on 31 January 2008 against Fredrik Neij, Gottfrid Svartholm, and Peter Sunde; and [[Carl LundstrÃ¶m]], a Swedish businessman who through his businesses sold services to the site. The prosecutor claimed the four worked together to administer, host, and develop the site and thereby facilitated other people's breach of copyright law. Some 34 cases of copyright infringements were originally listed, of which 21 were related to music files, 9 to movies, and 4 to games.<ref name=larsson /> One case involving music files was later dropped by the copyright holder who made the file available again on The Pirate Bay site. In addition, claims for damages of 117 million [[Swedish krona|kronor]] (US$13 million, â¬12.5 million) were filed.<ref name=timescharges>{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Harvey |date=18 February 2009 |url=http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/article5754740.ece |title=Half of Pirate Bay charges dropped |publisher=The Times | location=London}}</ref> The case was decided jointly by a judge, who was a member of several pro-copyright organisations, and three appointed [[laymen]].<ref> {{cite news |title=PiratnÃ¤mndeman fick lÃ¤mna uppdrag |publisher=[[Sydsvenskan]] |date=10 February 2009 |url=http://sydsvenskan.se/kultur-och-nojen/article412141/Piratnamndeman-fick-lamna-uppdrag.html |language=Swedish }} </ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Unga sympatisÃ¶rer och Ã¤ldre nÃ¤mndemÃ¤n |publisher=Blekinge LÃ¤ns Tidning |date=16 February 2009 |url=http://blt.se/nyheter/tt_inrikes/unga-sympatisorer-och-aldre-namndeman(1155188).gm |archiveurl=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:lOWorau1BVsJ:blt.se/nyheter/tt_inrikes/unga-sympatisorer-och-aldre-namndeman%281155188%29.gm%20Unga%20sympatis%C3%B6rer%20och%20%C3%A4ldre%20n%C3%A4mndem%C3%A4n&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us |archivedate=14 May 2010 |language=Swedish |accessdate=13 July 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2011}}(Google cache)</ref>
The trial started on 16 February 2009 in the [[TingsrÃ¤tt|district court]] (''[[tingsrÃ¤tt]]'') of [[Stockholm]], Sweden. The hearings ended on 3 March 2009 and the verdict was announced at 11:00 AM on Friday 17 April 2009: Peter Sunde, Fredrik Neij, Gottfrid Svartholm and Carl LundstrÃ¶m were all found guilty and sentenced to serve one year in prison and pay a fine of 30 million Swedish krona (app. [[Euro|â¬]]2.7 million or USD 3.5 million). All of the defendants appealed the verdict.
The appeal trial concluded on 15 October 2010 <ref>{{Cite news |author= Jenselius, Michael |title= Pirate Bay-rÃ¤ttegÃ¥ngen Ã¶ver â dom i november |url= http://www.idg.se/2.1085/1.346725/pirate-bay-rattegangen-over---dom-i-november |work= idg.se |publisher= [[IDG]] |language= Swedish |date= 18 October 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2010}}</ref> and the verdict was announced on 26 November. The appeal court shortened sentences of three of the defendants who appeared in court that day. Neij's sentence was reduced to 10 months, Sunde's to eight, and LundstrÃ¶m's to four.
